summary_generated: Federal Forage Fee Act of 1993 - Makes all grazing operations conducted on Federal lands subject to all applicable Federal, State, and local laws, including, but not limited to: (1) Animal Damage Control Act; (2) the Clean Air Act; (3) the Endangered Species Act; (4) the Federal Advisory Committee Act; (5) the Federal Grant and Cooperative Agreement Act; (6) the National Forest Management Act of 1976; (7) the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976; (8) the Federal Water Pollution Control Act; (9) the Granger-Thye Wilderness Act; (10) the Independent Offices Appropriations Act of 1952; (11) the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969; and (12) the Public Rangeland Improvement Act. <n>Amends the: (1) Western States' Update Act of 1973 to set forth the fee schedule for grazing operations in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Kansas, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming; and (2) Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to set forth the fee schedule for livestock grazing on Federal lands in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Kansas, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming. <n>
predicted_summary: Federal forage fee Act of 1993 - Amends the Department of Agriculture Act of 1949 to authorize the Secretary of Agriculture to establish a Federal forage fees system. <n>Directs the Secretary to establish: (1) a fee system for providing livestock forage on public lands; and (2) a system of payments to participating cooperative associations for the use of forage on such lands.Amends the following Acts to authorize appropriations for FY 2000 through 2005: (1) the Department of the Interior for land and water management; (2) the Departmentof Agriculture for the Forest Service and the National Park Service for certain personnel and activities; (3) the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, the Interior, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2000; (4) the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985; (5) the Department's Office of Management and Budget, and the Federal Emergency Management Agency, for FY 2001; (6) the General Services Administration for the acquisition of real and personal property, including mineral and geothermal leasing, mineral materials, and geothermal heat pump systems; and (7) the Energy Policy and Conservation Act, for the development of renewable energy resources, water conservation measures, and cost-effective technologies.sixteen western states means specified states located in the western region of the United States (including Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Kansas, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon, South Dakota, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming). Includes within the meaning of "sixteenwestern states" the states of Alaska, Colorado. Requires the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) to submit to the Secretary of the Interior: (1) the total number of aums reported by blm and authorized federal aumS, and (2) the weighted average private land lease rate in each state.grazing fee review and evaluation update of the 1986 final report dated April 30, 1992.<n>Defines "nonfee cost differential" as a value calculated annually by the Secretaries of Agriculture by multiplying the weighted difference in nonfee costs per aum between public land and private land by the input cost index determined annual by the department of agriculture.Directs the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior to: (1) calculate annually the federal forage fee by calculating the average of a specified wallpr for the preceding three years; and (2) include in the fee calculation the plf value ratio of the private lease forage value ratio into the forage value portion of theprivate land lease rate.e) the survey of nonfee costs used to calculate the nonfee cost differential shall be updated periodically by the Secretaries so as to reflect as accurately as possible the actual non fee costs incurred by the cattle and sheep industry that utilizes public lands in the sixteen western states.

summary_generated: . Merchant Marine of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act (Sec. 3) This bill directs the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President pro tempore of the Senate to award a Congressional Gold Medal to the U.S. Merchant Marine in honor of their dedicated and vital service during World War II. (Sec. 4) The medal shall be given to the American Merchant Marine Museum for display.
predicted_summary: Directs the Secretary of Transportation, acting through the Maritime Administration, to award a gold medal to the U.S. merchant marine personnel who, during their service, were integral in providing combat equipment, fuel, food, commodities, and raw materials to troops stationed overseas.Directs the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives to make appropriate arrangements for the presentation, on behalf of the Government of the United States, of a gold medal to the U.S. Merchant Marine Corps in recognition of its service during World War II, particularly its role in ensuring the efficient and reliable transoceanic transport of military equipment and personnel despite consistent and ongoing exposure to enemy combatants from both air and the sea.TABLE OF CONTENTS: <n> Title I: American Merchant Marine <n> Tile II: Women's Merchant Marine; <n>Title I: Americans Merchant Marine<n> - Directs the Secretary of the department in which the merchant marine is operating to issue regulations governing all operations of U.S. merchant marine vessels during World War II, including those in support of contingency operations. <n>Requires all merchant marine officers and men serving in contingency operations to be granted a leave of absence from duty during such period of service to enable them to perform their duties.The congressional gold medal is an appropriate way to shed further light on the service of the merchant marine in world war ii and the instrumental role they played in winning world war II.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on June 22, 2008. The summary of that version is repeated here.) Authorizes the Department of the Treasury to strike and sell duplicates in bronze of the gold medal struck under this Act at a price sufficient to cover the costs of the medals, including labor, materials, dies, use of machinery, and overhead expenses.

Fair Access to Investment Research Act of 2016 (Sec. 2) This bill directs the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to establish and implement a safe harbor" for certain investment fund research reports published by brokers and dealers. Such reports shall be deemed not to be "offers" under specified provisions of securities law, even if the broker or dealer participates in the registered offering of the investment fund\\'s securities. In implementing the safe harbor, the SEC must prohibit a self-regulatory organization from maintaining or enforcing a rule that would prevent a member from: (1) publishing or distributing a covered investment fund research report solely because the member is also participating in a registered offering or other distribution of the fund\\'s securities, or (2) participating in a registered offering or other distribution of the fund solely because the member has published a research report about it. The bill restricts the SEC from conditioning the safe harbor upon specified requirements."
predicted_summary: Instructs the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to propose to adopt regulations to provide that a covered investment fund research report that is published or distributed by a broker or dealer shall be deemed to be: (1) published by a Broker or dealer; and (2) distributed by an broker or dealers, without regard as to whether or not the research is disseminated by the broker or Dealer.Declares that the implementation of a safe harbor for covered investment funds is in the public interest and consistent with the purposes and duties of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), as well as any self-regulatory organization.The minimum float provision of a self-regulatory organization may not be imposed for any period exceeding the period of time referenced in specified federal regulations, or to prohibit the ability of a member to participate in a registered offering or other distribution of securities of a covered investment fund solely because the member has published or distributed a covered Investment Fund research report about such covered Investment fund or its securities.The application of the antifraud or antimanipulation provisions of the federal securities laws and rules adopted thereunder to a covered investment fund research report is limited to the extent that it is otherwise not subject to the content standards in the rules of any self-regulatory organization related to research reports, including those contained in the Rules governing communications with the public regarding investment companies or substantially similar standards.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on July 12, 2009. The summary of that version is repeated here.)<n><n>(Sec. 3) Amends the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, respectively, to grant the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regulatory authority over securities dealers and investment funds, including the authority to prohibit the sale or delivery of any security if the SEC finds that the transaction constitutes an unfair or deceptive act or practice.<n><n>Prescribes guidelines under which the SEC may: (1) refer an alleged violation to another entity; (2) prohibit the SEC from taking an enforcement action unless it first provides the entity with a reasonable opportunity to submit written notice of the violation; and (3) permit the SEC to assess and collect fees from violators of its rules, without regard to whether such violations were committed knowingly or willfully.Directs the Securities and Exchange Commission to deem to be a security listed on a national securities exchange, and not subject to specified laws of the investment company Act of 1940, any security that is listed on such exchange and that is not, according to the Act, subject to mandatory registration as a security by an investment company under such Act.The dealer about a covered investment fund or any securities issued by the covered investment Fund, but does not include a research report to the extent that the research report is published or distributed by thecovered investment fund, or any affiliate, of the covered Investment Fund.Securities Act of 1933 - Amends the securities act of 1933 to replace references to "research report" with references to the term "self-regulatory organization," except that such term shall not include an oral communication.

or (2) the spouse of any such officer at the time of such officer's death or on the date of such Officer's totally and permanently disabling injury.Amends the omnibus crime control and safe streets Act of 1968 to provide provisions for the establishment of survivor pensions for police officers who are the surviving spouses of officers who were killed in the line of duty and who died while on duty.If there is no surviving spouse or surviving child, but there are two surviving children of such officer, a pension equal to 20 percent of the applicable amount under section 1223 and paid to the children in equal shares; or there are three surviving parents of such officers, a Pension equal to 40 percent ofthe applicable amount, paid tothe parents in equal share shares.Provides that the amount used to determine the amount of an annual pension under this subpart shall be the greater of: (1) the annual base salary of the public safety officer at the time of his or her death, adjusted for inflation; or (2) the annual annuity paid to the widow or widower of such officer, adjusted in accordance with this Act.Directs the bureau of labor statistics to adjust the amounts used to determine the amount of an annual pension under this subpart immediately before such October 1 to reflect the annual percentage change in the consumer price index for all urban consumers, occurring in the one-year period ending on june 1 immediately preceding such october 1(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on May 10, 2003.) Provides that the maximum amount of a scholarship award is for a kindergarten, elementary school, or secondary school student.Sets forth requirements for scholarship applications and certification of eligibility.The maximum amount of a scholarship award for a postsecondary student shall not exceed the lesser of: (1) the average cost of attendance at a state university in the state in which the student resides, for a state resident carrying the same academic workload as the student, with the same number of dependents as the Student, and residing in the same type of housing as thestudent; and (2) the number of Dependents as theStudent, with The maximum award may not be used for housing assistance.The maximum duration of each scholarship award under this title is the period of time normally required for the completion of a high school diploma by a student in the grade that the recipient is in at the time the award commences, as determined by the Secretary of Education.The Secretary of Education is authorized to enter into agreements with eligible institutions in which any student receiving a scholarship award under title IV part A (Student Assistance) has enrolled or has been accepted for enrollment.The term "deceased or disabled officer" means a public safety officer with respect to whom the bureau of justice assistance has determined, in accordance with the omnibus crime control and safe streets Act of 1968, that such public safety Officer has died as the direct and proximate result of a personal injury sustained in the line of duty.Defines dependent child as a child of a deceased or disabled officer, including a stepchild or an adopted child, who: (1) is living with or receiving regular support contributions from such deceased or disability officer at the time of the officer's death or at the times of the officers' totally and permanently disabling injury; and (2) at the start of the academic year for which a scholarship award is received, is 25 years of age or under.Public safety officer is the term "public safety officer" and the meaning given in the omnibus crime control and safe streets Act of 1968 as added by this act.Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to prohibit the Attorney General from using specified funds for a pilot program to compensate citizens for the cost of filing a police report in lieu of filing suit in connection with a criminal investigation or prosecution.

summary_generated: Authorizes the Secretary of Energy to enter into one or more long-term contracts, for up to 30 years each, for the procurement, from a facility located within 25 miles of a current or former Department of Energy defense nuclear facility, of products and services necessary to support waste cleanup and modernization activities at such facilities.

Prohibits payment to the contractor of cost plus a percentage of cost or cost plus an fixed fee.Exempts contractors from applicable requirements that would increase the cost of performing a contract that is imposed by regulation by a federal, state, or local governmental agency or imposed by an act of Congress after the date on which the contract is entered into unless the regulation is issued under a specified act of congress.Requires the contractor to negotiate an amendment to a contract providing full compensation to the contractor for the increased cost incurred in order to comply with any additional requirement of law. Permits a contractor to elect to be governed by a change in a requirement that would reduce the cost of performing the contract that is adopted by regulation by a Federal, State, or local governmental agency after enactment of this Act, except an act of Congress.The Secretary of energy may make a payment under a contract term and pay any other costs assumed by the Secretary as a result of the termination out of any appropriations available to the Department of Energy for operating expenses for the fiscal year in which the termination occurs or for any subsequent fiscal year.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the House on March 12, 2003. Provides that a contractor under a contract under specified provisions of the Occupational Safety and Health Act of 1970 or a subcontractor of such contractor shall not be liable under federal, state, or local law for any injury, cost, damage, expense, or other relief on a claim by any person for death, personal injury, illness, loss of or damage to property, or economic loss caused by a release or threatened release of a hazardous substance, pollutant, or contaminant during performance of the contract unless the release is caused by conduct of the contractor ''Directs the Secretary of energy and contractors under the Secretary's supervision to give preference in entering into a contract with a private entity for products to be acquired or services to be performed at a qualifying department of energy site to an entity that is otherwise qualified and within the competitive range.Applies this Act only to contracts for an environmental management and restoration activity that is entered into after the enactment date of this Act.
